sen.j: あぶり餅（あぶりもち）は、黄粉をまぶした親指大の餅を竹串に刺し、炭火であぶったあと白味噌のタレをぬった餅菓子または、串にさしてあぶったおかきや煎餅のこと。
sen.e: Aburimochi is a kind of rice cake sweets, which is made of thumb-sized rice cakes dredged with soybean flour, skewered with a bamboo stick, roasted over charcoal fire, and then basted with white bean pastes, or otherwise okaki (cracker mix) and senbei (rice crackers) skewered with a stick.

sen.j: 京都市北区 (京都市)の今宮神社 (京都市)や同右京区嵯峨 (京都市)の清凉寺、石川県金沢市金沢五社の神明宮などにある和菓子屋が有名。
sen.e: Aburimochi are sold at many Japanese sweets shops, among which the famous are the shops located in the precincts of Imamiya jinja shrine in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Seiryo-ji temple in Saga, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Jinmei-gu shrine of Kanazawa gosha (five shrines of Kanazawa) in Kanazawa City, Ishikawa Prefecture, and so on.

sen.j: 特に今宮神社の店は、平安時代頃からある日本最古の和菓子屋とされ、今宮神社参道で応仁の乱や飢饉のとき庶民に振舞ったといういわれがある。
sen.e: Especially, the shop in the Imamiya jinja shrine is said to be the oldest Japanese sweets shop operating since Heian era, which is told to have served aburimochi to starved people on the entrance path to the shrine at the times of Onin war and other famines.

sen.j: またあぶり餅で使われる竹串は今宮神社に奉納された斎串（いぐし）で、今宮神社で毎年4月の第2日曜に行われるやすらい祭の鬼の持つ花傘の下に入ると御利益があるのをたとえとし、食べることで病気・厄除けの御利益があるとされ親しまれている。
sen.e: Aburimochi are popular as they are believed to bring the people who eat them the benefits of expelling diseases and evils because aburimochi are skewered with purified bamboo sticks dedicated to the shrine, in the same way as any one may receive benefits if he joins oni (a devil) under its umbrella with floral decoration for the Yasurai festival held at the Imamiya jinja shrine on the second Sunday of every April.
